content:
I'm sure there are several ways to skin this cat. Here's how I would do it. This requires the addon, "Import ExportTools NG" ( https://github.com/thunderbird/import-export-tools-ng/releases ).

- Extract the file from your backup that represents the folder that contains the messages you want to recover into a temporary folder in a convenient place (Desktop?). It might be a pair of files called "Trash" and "Trash.msf".

- Create a temporary Local Folder in Thunderbird. Right-click on it and choose <ImportExportTools NG | Import mbox files | Individual mbox files> from the context menu. Navigate to the temporary folder that has your extracted files, select those files and click "Open".

- This will import all messages from the archived folder to your local folder. You can now delete everything you DON'T want, or copy or move the missing messages to their final destination.

- Delete the temporary local Thunderbird folder when you're done.
creator: rednoise

content:
I know of two possible causes of this error message. Notice that the error message says two non-specific things. One is that there is the mail server has a problem that has resulted in there actually being insufficient system storage. You can't do anything about this except to contact your email host for confirmation. They have to fix it.

The other part of the error message, about "exceeding the allowed number of recipients" is misleading. Another user in this forum was getting the same error message and discovered that the email host had changed the outgoing server address, but neglected to tell their users. Once the new SMTP address was learned and updated within Thunderbird, all was well again. See this conversation for more context:

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1560273

So, confirm the server addresses with your email provider, and if you would like help changing them in Thunderbird, let us know.

content:
TB doesn't have its own LDAP server. You choose a remote one - typically the one your email provider uses - at TB menu > Composition > Addressing and you can override that one at TB menu > Account Settings > Composition & Addressing > Addressing.

You can see how to configure the remote LDAP server at https://wiki.mozilla.org/Thunderbird:Help_Documentation:Connecting_to_an_LDAP_address_book.

I don't know how to tell what version the remote LDAP server is.

content:
Alan37 said
My apologies. If I select a cell in a table, right-click, and choose the Select All item in the pop up menu I can then copy and paste the whole table. Slightly weird operability but it works. Strangely, the border colour is not copied across.

I went to the trouble of looking at tables copied from Excel at one point as most of the formatting did not arrive in Thunderbird. I though that was a poor showing of what you see is what you get. What I found was Excel only put the basic table and data on the clipboard as HTML it put everything on the clipboard in RTF. Thunderbird defaults to picking plain text or HTML. I would not put it past Thunderbird to also leave out the styling. Personally I do not use grids in emails unless I am desperate as they generally present particularly poorly on phone screens. Lots and lots of left and right scrolling as the screen is so much smaller that the desktop.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Matt, I have very little use for tables as such in email messages. I do have three email recipients who use crappy email clients that don't show HTML quotations properly. When I'm sending quotations to these people I put them in single-cell tables with nice borders, that way everyone is happy. Instead of setting up a table from scratch for each quotation I want to keep a table in my templates folder and just paste it into the emails I'm writing. I set the table border colour in Thunderbird with HTML, so the bird's lack of facility with RTF shouldn't be an issue.

content:
They recommend port 587 for the outgoing, but don't state if the security is STARTTLS or None. If it's None, the authentication would be 'password, transmitted insecurely'. Also, the User Name might be the full address instead of just the part before @.

A timeout can also be caused by AV scanning of outgoing mail. To test, temporarily remove (not disable) the AV, unless it's Windows Security.

content:
Hi

If you want to use Thunderbird and iCloud together you have to generate an app specific password when you log into the Apple ID website.

Generate an App-Specific Password Go to appleid.apple.com and sign in. Navigate to the Sign-In and Security section. Click on App-Specific Passwords. Select Generate an app-specific password and click Create. Copy password, It looks like xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx.

Open Thunderbird, Account Settings > Account Actions > Add Mail Account. Enter your name and iCloud email address, settings: Incoming Server (IMAP) Server: imap.mail.me.com Port: 993 Connection Security: SSL/TLS Authentication: Normal password Username: Your full email (e.g., username@icloud.com)

Outgoing Server (SMTP) Server: smtp.mail.me.com Port: 587 Connection Security: STARTTLS Authentication: Normal password Username: Your full email

When Thunderbird asks for your password during the setup, paste the App-Specific Password you generated in Step 1, not your regular iCloud password.

content:
A threaded view is a way to show conversations. See here: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/message-threading-thunderbird

In list view, you will see a little arrow in the top message of a conversation. I don't think that there is a similar indicator of threads in cards view. Another indicator in both views is the View menu (or film roll button) > Sort by > Threaded (see it is checked).

The top message represents that individual message *and* the whole threaded conversation, so deleting it deletes all the messages in the conversation.

Did you mean to mark this problem as solved?
